interestingFact: There are 195 countries, including 193 UN members and 2 observers, spread across seven continents globally.
Mount Everest, the world's tallest mountain at 8,848 meters, lies in Nepal, attracting climbers from across the world.
The Pyramids of Giza, built over 4,500 years ago, are the last remaining wonders of the Ancient World, attracting millions.
Australia’s Great Barrier Reef, spanning 2,300 km, is the largest coral reef system, home to thousands of marine species.
The Amazon Rainforest, covering over 5.5 million square kilometers, produces 20% of the world’s oxygen, crucial for biodiversity.
The Eiffel Tower, originally a temporary exhibit in 1889, remains France’s most visited landmark, welcoming millions yearly.
Russia, covering over 17 million square kilometers, spans 11 time zones, making it the largest country by land area worldwide.
The Great Wall of China stretches over 21,000 km and, despite popular myths, is barely visible from space with the naked eye.
India’s Taj Mahal, a UNESCO site, was built in the 17th century by Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal.
The United States has the largest economy, contributing over 25% of global GDP, with Silicon Valley leading tech innovations.
Canada has the world's longest coastline, stretching over 202,080 km, and is home to vast boreal forests and fresh water lakes.
Japan consists of 6,800 islands, with Honshu being the largest. It is known for its rich culture, technology, and traditions.
Germany, Europe’s largest economy, is famous for its automotive industry, Oktoberfest, and historical landmarks like the Berlin Wall.
Italy’s Colosseum, built around AD 80, is the largest ancient amphitheater, once hosting gladiator battles for Roman entertainment.
South Africa, with 11 official languages, was the first African nation to host the FIFA World Cup in 2010, uniting cultures.
